title: 106_hr1553
content:
The Act is titled the "National Weather Service and Related Agencies Authorization Act of 1999". It defines the terms "Administrator" as the head of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, and "Secretary" as the head of the Department of Commerce. The National Weather Service and Related Agencies Authorization Act of 1999 authorizes appropriations for Operations, Research, and Facilities activities of the National Weather Service. $617,897,000 is allocated for fiscal year 2000 and $617,897,000 for fiscal year 2001, with specific amounts designated for Local Warnings and Forecasts, Advanced Hydrological Prediction System, Susquehanna River Basin Flood Systems, and Aviation Forecasts. For fiscal years 2000 and 2001, specific allocations include $4,000,000 for Aviation Forecasts, $4,000,000 for Weather Forecast Offices Facilities Maintenance, $37,081,000 for Central Forecast Guidance, $3,090,000 for Atmospheric and Hydrological Research, $39,325,000 for Next Generation Weather Radar (NEXRAD), $7,573,000 for Automated Surface Observing System (ASOS), and $38,002,000 for Advanced Weather Interactive. For fiscal years 2000 and 2001, $970,000 is allocated for National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Weather Radio transmitters in Illinois, and $69,632,000 and $70,120,000 are authorized for Procurement, Acquisition, and Construction activities of the National Weather Service. In fiscal years 2000 and 2001, funding is allocated for various weather-related systems including NEXRAD, ASOS, AWIPS, Computer Facilities Upgrades, Radiosonde Replacement, and NOAA Operations Center Rehabilitation. The National Weather Service is responsible for forecasts, weather warnings, storm warnings, and data collection to protect life and property in all 50 states, the District of Columbia, and the Territories. Funding is allocated for Weather Forecast Office construction in fiscal years 2000 and 2001. The National Weather Service is responsible for providing oceanographic data, hydrometeorological guidance, core forecast information, marine and aviation forecasts, and warnings. They are prohibited from offering services already provided by the private sector unless it involves vital weather warnings and forecasts for public safety or international aviation agreements. The National Weather Service provides various meteorological information and services, including oceanographic data, hydrometeorological guidance, and forecasts. Amendments to the Act of October 1, 1890 involve removing certain sections and requiring a report on non-compliant activities. Congress emphasizes the need for the National Weather Service to consider closing local weather service offices. The Congress urges the National Weather Service to consider the dangerous weather patterns in Wind Zone IV, also known as tornado alley, before closing any local weather service offices. SEC. 4. ATMOSPHERIC RESEARCH. The Secretary is authorized to appropriate funds for Atmospheric Research Operations, Research, and Facilities, including $173,250,000 for fiscal year 2000 and $173,250,000 for fiscal year 2001. Additionally, $126,200,000 for fiscal year 2000 and $126,200,000 for fiscal year 2001 is allocated for Climate and Air Quality Research, with a portion designated for Interannual and Seasonal Climate Research. For fiscal years 2000 and 2001, funding is allocated as follows: $34,600,000 for Long-Term Climate and Air Quality Research, $69,700,000 for Climate and Global Change, $5,000,000 for Global Learning and Observations to Benefit the Environment (GLOBE), and $47,050,000 for Atmospheric Programs, including $36,600,000 for Weather. For fiscal years 2000 and 2001, funding is allocated as follows: $36,600,000 for Weather Research, $4,350,000 for Wind Profiler, and $6,100,000 for Solar-Terrestrial Services and Research. Additionally, $10,040,000 for fiscal year 2000 and $14,160,000 for fiscal year 2001 are authorized for Atmospheric Research Procurement, Acquisition, and Construction activities. In fiscal years 2000 and 2001, $5,700,000 and $8,000,000 are allocated for the Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Laboratory Supercomputer, and $4,340,000 and $6,160,000 for the Advanced Composition Explorer (ACE) Follow-On Satellite/GEOSTORM. SEC. 5. NATIONAL ENVIRONMENTAL SATELLITE, DATA AND INFORMATION SERVICE. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration is authorized to receive funding for environmental research and development, including Satellite Observing Systems such as the Global Disaster Information Network. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration is authorized to receive funding for environmental research and development, including Satellite Observing Systems like the Global Disaster Information Network. Funding allocations include $4,000,000 for Ocean Remote Sensing and $53,236,000 for Environmental Observing Services for fiscal years 2000 and 2001. Additionally, $43,856,000 for each fiscal year is designated for Environmental Data Management Systems, with portions allocated to Data and Information Services and Environmental Data Management Systems. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration is authorized to receive funding for environmental research and development, including Satellite Observing Systems. Funding allocations include $12,335,000 for Environmental Data Systems Modernization in fiscal year 2001. Additionally, $413,657,000 for fiscal year 2000 and $476,183,000 for fiscal year 2001 are authorized for Procurement, Acquisition, and Construction activities related to the National Environmental Satellite, Data and Information Service. Of these amounts, $410,612,000 for fiscal year 2000 and $473,803,000 for fiscal year 2001 are designated for Systems Acquisition. Funding for the procurement and launch of Polar Orbiting Environmental Satellites (POES), National Polar-Orbiting Operational Environmental Satellite System (NPOESS), and Geostationary Operational Environmental NEXT follow-on Satellites (GOES N-Q) is allocated as follows: $140,979,000 for fiscal year 2000 and $114,594,000 for fiscal year 2001 for POES, $80,100,000 for fiscal year 2000 and $113,600,000 for fiscal year 2001 for NPOESS, and $189,533,000 for fiscal year 2000 and $245,609,000 for fiscal year 2001 for GOES N-Q. Construction funding for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Operations Center Rehabilitation is allocated as $3,045,000 for fiscal year 2000 and $2,380,000 for fiscal year 2001. SEC. 6. FACILITIES.

Authorized funding for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration to support the David Skaggs Research Center in Boulder, Colorado is $3,850,000 for fiscal year 2000 and $3,850,000 for fiscal year 2001.

SEC. 7. ELIGIBILITY FOR AWARDS. The Administrator will exclude individuals from grant agreements made after fiscal year 1999 by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration if they received funds for a project without a competitive award process, except as authorized by law. This exclusion lasts for 5 years. An exception applies if the funds were received due to membership in a specified class eligible for assistance according to a legal formula. The term "grant agreement" refers to a legal instrument transferring value for a public purpose, excluding property acquisition for the US Government's direct benefit. It does not include cooperative agreements or cooperative research and development agreements. The Administrator will publish research grant abstracts online. Funds must comply with the Buy American Act. Congress requires notice. SEC. 10. Sense of the Congress is for entities receiving financial assistance to purchase American-made equipment. The Secretary of Commerce must provide a notice to recipients about this requirement. SEC. 11 prohibits contracts. SEC. 11 prohibits contracts for individuals who falsely label products as "Made in America" when they are not. If found guilty, they will be ineligible to receive any contracts funded by this Act.
